title: Judges Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Judges chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Judges Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Judges Chapter 6.

questions.question: For how many years did the LORD deliver the children of Israel into the hand of Midian?
options: Seven years
Five years
Ten years
Three years
questions.correctAnswer: Seven years
questions.explanation: Judges 6:1 states that Israel was delivered into the hand of Midian for seven years.

questions.question: Where did the children of Israel make dens to hide from the Midianites?
options: Mountains, caves, and strongholds
Valleys and rivers
Deserts and plains
Cities and towns
questions.correctAnswer: Mountains, caves, and strongholds
questions.explanation: Judges 6:2 describes that Israel made dens in the mountains, caves, and strongholds to hide from Midianites.

questions.question: Who came against Israel when they had sown their crops?
options: Midianites, Amalekites, and children of the east
Egyptians and Philistines
Babylonians and Assyrians
Canaanites and Hittites
questions.correctAnswer: Midianites, Amalekites, and children of the east
questions.explanation: Judges 6:3 says the Midianites, Amalekites, and children of the east came against Israel after sowing.

questions.question: What did the Midianites destroy when they encamped against Israel?
options: The increase of the earth
The cities of Israel
The Ark of the Covenant
The altars of Baal
questions.correctAnswer: The increase of the earth
questions.explanation: Judges 6:4 states they destroyed the increase of the earth and left no sustenance for Israel.

questions.question: How were the Midianites described in their multitude?
options: Like grasshoppers
Like lions
Like eagles
Like stars in the sky
questions.correctAnswer: Like grasshoppers
questions.explanation: Judges 6:5 compares the multitude of Midianites to grasshoppers.

questions.question: What was Israel’s condition because of the Midianites?
options: Greatly impoverished
Victorious and strong
Peaceful and secure
Prosperous and wealthy
questions.correctAnswer: Greatly impoverished
questions.explanation: Judges 6:6 reports that Israel was greatly impoverished because of the Midianites.

questions.question: Who did the LORD send to the children of Israel after they cried to Him?
options: A prophet
An angel
A king
A priest
questions.correctAnswer: A prophet
questions.explanation: Judges 6:8 says the LORD sent a prophet to the children of Israel.

questions.question: What did the LORD remind Israel He had done for them?
options: Brought them up from Egypt and gave them their land
Built the temple in Jerusalem
Made them kings over other nations
Given them wealth and gold
questions.correctAnswer: Brought them up from Egypt and gave them their land
questions.explanation: Judges 6:8-9 describes God reminding Israel of their deliverance from Egypt and giving them the land.

questions.question: Where was the angel of the LORD sitting when he appeared to Gideon?
options: Under an oak in Ophrah
On Mount Sinai
By the Jordan River
In the tabernacle
questions.correctAnswer: Under an oak in Ophrah
questions.explanation: Judges 6:11 states the angel of the LORD sat under an oak in Ophrah.

questions.question: What was Gideon doing when the angel appeared to him?
options: Threshing wheat by the winepress
Building an altar
Fighting Midianites
Praying in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Threshing wheat by the winepress
questions.explanation: Judges 6:11 says Gideon was threshing wheat by the winepress to hide it from the Midianites.

questions.question: True or False: Gideon was confident and proud when the angel called him 'mighty man of valour.'
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 6:13 shows Gideon doubted and questioned why the LORD had forsaken Israel despite being called mighty man of valour.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD promised Gideon that He would be with him and he would strike Midian as one man.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 6:16 records the LORD's promise to Gideon that He would be with him and he would smite Midian as one man.

questions.question: True or False: Gideon immediately obeyed the LORD's command to destroy the altar of Baal in the daytime.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 6:27 explains Gideon did it at night because he feared his father's household and the men of the city.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Gideon called the altar he built '__________.'
options: Jehovahshalom
Bethel
Shiloh
Gilgal
questions.correctAnswer: Jehovahshalom
questions.explanation: Judges 6:24 states that Gideon named the altar Jehovahshalom, meaning 'The LORD is Peace.'

questions.question: What sign did Gideon ask from God to know He would save Israel by Gideon's hand?
options: A fleece of wool with dew only on it
A burning bush
A pillar of fire
A mighty wind
questions.correctAnswer: A fleece of wool with dew only on it
questions.explanation: Judges 6:37-38 records Gideon asking for a sign involving a fleece of wool to confirm God's promise.

medium.title: Judges Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Judges Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Judges 6, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in difficult times?
options: God is always with us and strengthens us to overcome challenges.
We must rely solely on our own strength to solve problems.
God abandons His people when they suffer.
Trials mean we have been forsaken by God.
questions.correctAnswer: God is always with us and strengthens us to overcome challenges.
questions.explanation: Judges 6:12, 16, and 23 show that God reassures Gideon that He is with him and will give him strength, teaching us to trust God's presence and power through trials.

questions.question: How does Judges 6 teach about obedience and its importance in the Christian life?
options: Disobedience leads to hardship, but obedience brings deliverance.
Obedience is optional if we feel doubtful.
It is better to follow our own plans than God's instructions.
God does not require obedience from His people.
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience leads to hardship, but obedience brings deliverance.
questions.explanation: Verses 8-10 and 25-27 explain how Israel's disobedience led to oppression, and Gideon's obedience to God's command brought freedom, emphasizing the importance of obeying God.

questions.question: A believer feels insignificant and unqualified for service. What encouragement from Judges 6 can you share?
options: God can use the least and weakest to accomplish great things.
Only the strong and wealthy are chosen by God.
Qualifications depend on human status and wealth.
God ignores those who feel unimportant.
questions.correctAnswer: God can use the least and weakest to accomplish great things.
questions.explanation: Gideon expressed his low status in Judges 6:15, but God promised His presence and success (6:16), showing that God empowers the humble and weak.

questions.question: What does Judges 6 teach about prayer and seeking signs when facing uncertainty in God's will?
options: It is acceptable to ask God for confirmation through signs.
Seeking signs is a sign of weak faith and should be avoided.
God never responds to requests for confirmation.
We must act without any assurance from God.
questions.correctAnswer: It is acceptable to ask God for confirmation through signs.
questions.explanation: Gideon asked God for signs with the fleece in Judges 6:36-40, showing that seeking God's confirmation in prayer is a biblical practice.

questions.question: How does Judges 6 illustrate the role of courage and obedience in witnessing and serving God?
options: Gideon boldly destroyed the altar of Baal despite opposition.
Fear should prevent us from obeying God’s commands.
We should avoid conflict even if it means disobedience.
Witnessing is optional and private.
questions.correctAnswer: Gideon boldly destroyed the altar of Baal despite opposition.
questions.explanation: Verses 25-32 show Gideon's courageous act to tear down idols, teaching that obedience to God requires boldness even when facing opposition.

questions.question: What does Judges 6 teach about God's faithfulness in response to sincere prayer and repentance?
options: God hears and delivers those who cry out to Him sincerely.
God ignores the cries of His people.
Repentance has no effect on God’s actions.
Prayer is ineffective during trials.
questions.correctAnswer: God hears and delivers those who cry out to Him sincerely.
questions.explanation: Judges 6:6-8 records Israel crying to the LORD and God sending a prophet, showing God’s faithfulness to hear and act upon sincere repentance and prayer.

questions.question: How does Judges 6 encourage humility in service to God?
options: Gideon acknowledged his lowly status before God called him.
Pride is necessary to lead others effectively.
Only the proud can be used by God.
Humility is irrelevant in spiritual leadership.
questions.correctAnswer: Gideon acknowledged his lowly status before God called him.
questions.explanation: In Judges 6:15, Gideon humbly admits he is the least in his family, showing humility as a godly attitude in receiving God's call.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 6 teaches that God’s presence alone guarantees success, regardless of our obedience or faith.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 6:10 and 14 show that God’s help is linked to Israel’s obedience and Gideon’s faith; success depends on obeying God and trusting Him.

questions.question: True or False: Gideon’s initial doubt and request for signs demonstrate that God welcomes honest questions and faith struggles.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Gideon’s questions in Judges 6:13 and his requests for signs in 6:36-39 show that God patiently responds to honest doubts and encourages faith development.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear of opposition when standing for God. What practical lesson from Judges 6 would you share?
options: God provides assurance and peace to face fears.
Avoid opposition by compromising your faith.
Fear means you should step back from God’s work.
Opposition shows God has abandoned you.
questions.correctAnswer: God provides assurance and peace to face fears.
questions.explanation: Judges 6:23 records God saying 'Peace be unto thee; fear not,' showing God’s promise of peace to overcome fear in serving Him.

questions.question: How does Judges 6 show the importance of community and fellowship in spiritual battles?
options: Gideon gathered men from Manasseh, Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali to fight together.
Spiritual battles are fought alone without others.
Community has no role in God’s deliverance.
Fellowship weakens personal faith.
questions.correctAnswer: Gideon gathered men from Manasseh, Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali to fight together.
questions.explanation: Verses 34-35 show Gideon rallying support from various tribes, highlighting the biblical principle of unity and fellowship in God’s work.

questions.question: What does the story of the angel consuming the offering with fire teach about God's power and holiness?
options: God’s presence is powerful and demands reverence.
God is indifferent to worship and offerings.
Fire symbolizes human strength, not divine power.
God accepts any kind of worship without reverence.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s presence is powerful and demands reverence.
questions.explanation: Judges 6:20-21 describes the angel consuming the offering with fire, demonstrating God's holiness and the seriousness of approaching Him rightly.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Gideon built an altar and called it ________, meaning 'The LORD is peace.'
options: Jehovahshalom
Bethel
Shiloh
Gilgal
questions.correctAnswer: Jehovahshalom
questions.explanation: Judges 6:24 states that Gideon built an altar and named it Jehovahshalom, signifying the peace the LORD brings.

questions.question: According to Judges 6, what is a practical way to demonstrate faith and obedience in difficult circumstances?
options: Acting promptly on God's instructions even when afraid.
Waiting for perfect conditions before obeying.
Ignoring God's commands due to fear.
Relying on human strength alone.
questions.correctAnswer: Acting promptly on God's instructions even when afraid.
questions.explanation: Gideon obeyed God’s command to tear down the altar by night despite fear (Judges 6:27), teaching practical obedience in trials.

questions.question: How does Judges 6 encourage perseverance through trials?
options: God’s presence and promises enable perseverance.
Trials mean God has forsaken us permanently.
Give up when faced with adversity.
Avoid trusting God during hardship.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s presence and promises enable perseverance.
questions.explanation: Judges 6:16 and 23 show God’s assurance to Gideon that He will be with him, encouraging perseverance through reliance on God.

questions.question: What lesson about spiritual leadership can be learned from Gideon's example in Judges 6?
options: True leaders trust God, act in obedience, and rally others to His cause.
Leadership is about personal power and control.
Spiritual leaders should avoid confrontation at all costs.
Leadership requires no faith or dependence on God.
questions.correctAnswer: True leaders trust God, act in obedience, and rally others to His cause.
questions.explanation: Judges 6:14-35 shows Gideon trusting God, obeying His commands, and gathering people, illustrating godly leadership.

hard.title: Judges Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Judges Chapter 6.

questions.question: What was the initial cause of Israel's oppression by the Midianites according to Judges 6?
options: Israel did evil in the sight of the LORD
Israel failed to build strongholds
Israel worshipped Baal openly
Israel refused to fight their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Israel did evil in the sight of the LORD
questions.explanation: Judges 6:1 states that because the children of Israel did evil in the sight of the LORD, He delivered them into the hand of Midian for seven years.

questions.question: How did the Midianites and their allies devastate the land of Israel as described in Judges 6?
options: They destroyed the produce and left no sustenance
They built fortresses to control the land
They poisoned the wells and rivers
They enslaved the Israelites directly
questions.correctAnswer: They destroyed the produce and left no sustenance
questions.explanation: Judges 6:4 explains that the Midianites encamped against Israel, destroyed the increase of the earth, and left no sustenance for Israel, neither sheep, nor ox, nor ass.

questions.question: The angel of the LORD addressed Gideon as 'a mighty man of valour.' What literary device is used in this greeting considering Gideon's initial self-perception?
options: Irony, since Gideon felt weak and insignificant
Metaphor, equating him to a lion
Hyperbole, exaggerating his strength
Foreshadowing his future kingship
questions.correctAnswer: Irony, since Gideon felt weak and insignificant
questions.explanation: Judges 6:12 shows the angel calling Gideon 'mighty man of valour' while Gideon himself expresses doubt about his ability due to his family's low status (Judges 6:15), illustrating irony.

questions.question: What sign did Gideon request from God to confirm his calling?
options: That dew would fall only on a fleece while the ground remained dry
That fire would consume his offering
That an angel would appear again
That his family would support him openly
questions.correctAnswer: That dew would fall only on a fleece while the ground remained dry
questions.explanation: Judges 6:37-38 records Gideon's request to put a fleece on the threshing floor to confirm God's promise, desiring dew on the fleece alone as a sign.

questions.question: What does the Hebrew name 'Jerubbaal' given to Gideon mean, and how does it reflect the cultural context?
options: Let Baal plead against him, indicating a challenge to Baal worship
The Lord is my shepherd, showing devotion to God
Mighty warrior of Israel, emphasizing strength
Chosen deliverer, highlighting his role
questions.correctAnswer: Let Baal plead against him, indicating a challenge to Baal worship
questions.explanation: Judges 6:32 shows Gideon called Jerubbaal meaning 'Let Baal plead against him,' which reflects the cultural confrontation between Yahweh worship and Baal idolatry.

questions.question: What cultural practice did Gideon fear when he destroyed his father’s altar to Baal?
options: Reprisal from his family and townspeople
Punishment by the Midianites
Divine wrath from Baal
Loss of inheritance rights
questions.correctAnswer: Reprisal from his family and townspeople
questions.explanation: Judges 6:27 reveals Gideon’s fear of his father’s household and men of the city, so he destroyed the altar by night to avoid immediate retaliation.

questions.question: Which phrase best describes the method of divine confirmation used by the angel of the LORD with Gideon's offering?
options: Fire from the rock consuming the meat and cakes
A thunderstorm signaling approval
An earthquake shaking the altar
A voice from heaven speaking
questions.correctAnswer: Fire from the rock consuming the meat and cakes
questions.explanation: Judges 6:21 describes the angel touching the flesh and unleavened cakes with a staff, causing fire to rise from the rock and consume them, confirming the divine presence.

questions.question: How does Gideon's initial threshing of wheat in a winepress symbolize the historical and cultural pressures Israel faced?
options: It illustrates the need for secrecy due to Midianite oppression
It shows Israel’s agricultural prosperity
It reflects a ritual purification practice
It indicates Gideon’s wealth and status
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates the need for secrecy due to Midianite oppression
questions.explanation: Judges 6:11 states Gideon was threshing wheat in a winepress to hide it from the Midianites, symbolizing Israel’s fear and the loss of freedom under foreign oppression.

questions.question: What is the significance of the altar Gideon built called Jehovahshalom?
options: It means 'The LORD is peace,' signifying God's peace after fear
It means 'The LORD is judge,' emphasizing divine justice
It means 'The LORD is king,' indicating kingship authority
It means 'The LORD is salvation,' reflecting deliverance
questions.correctAnswer: It means 'The LORD is peace,' signifying God's peace after fear
questions.explanation: Judges 6:24 shows Gideon naming the altar Jehovahshalom, meaning 'The LORD is peace,' highlighting God's reassurance after the fear of seeing the angel.

questions.question: True or False: The Midianites and their allies were described as coming like grasshoppers in number, emphasizing their overwhelming multitude.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 6:5 compares the Midianites and their camels to grasshoppers in multitude, emphasizing their vast numbers and threat.

questions.question: Which other biblical event is foreshadowed by the fire consuming Gideon’s offering in Judges 6?
options: Elijah’s sacrifice on Mount Carmel
Abraham's offering of Isaac
Fire falling on Sodom
The burning bush encounter
questions.correctAnswer: Elijah’s sacrifice on Mount Carmel
questions.explanation: The fire from heaven consuming the offering in Judges 6:21 prefigures the similar divine fire consuming Elijah’s offering in 1 Kings 18, both demonstrating God's power over Baal.

questions.question: What was the role of the prophet sent by the LORD to Israel according to Judges 6:8-10?
options: To remind Israel of their deliverance and call them to obedience
To announce immediate judgment without hope
To call for a military alliance against Midian
To instruct Israel to worship Baal instead
questions.correctAnswer: To remind Israel of their deliverance and call them to obedience
questions.explanation: Judges 6:8-10 reveals the prophet reminded Israel of God's past deliverance from Egypt and admonished them for not obeying God's voice, calling for repentance.

questions.question: How does Gideon's interaction with God reflect a common theme in the Old Testament regarding divine-human encounters?
options: Initial human doubt followed by divine reassurance
Immediate unquestioning faith and obedience
Violent confrontation between God and man
God speaking only through natural phenomena
questions.correctAnswer: Initial human doubt followed by divine reassurance
questions.explanation: Gideon questions God's presence and power (Judges 6:13) but receives reassurance and a mission from God (Judges 6:14-16), reflecting a common biblical motif of human doubt met with divine encouragement.

questions.question: What does the sending of messengers to Manasseh, Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali in Judges 6:34-35 indicate about Israel's tribal alliances?
options: Gideon was gathering a coalition of northern tribes for battle
Gideon was sending for reinforcements to build altars
The tribes were being called to worship Baal
The tribes were being expelled from the land
questions.correctAnswer: Gideon was gathering a coalition of northern tribes for battle
questions.explanation: Judges 6:34-35 shows Gideon assembling forces from several northern tribes, illustrating the political and military alliances necessary to confront the Midianite threat.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The Midianites, Amalekites, and children of the east came up against Israel and encamped in the valley of ______.
options: Jezreel
Gilboa
Shiloh
Bethel
questions.correctAnswer: Jezreel
questions.explanation: Judges 6:33 states that the Midianites and their allies pitched in the valley of Jezreel, a significant historical and prophetic location in Israel.

questions.question: What does Gideon's request to test God with the fleece twice teach us about faith development in biblical narratives?
options: Faith often grows through repeated reassurance
Faith requires no evidence or signs
Faith is immediate and without doubt
Faith is unrelated to divine signs
questions.correctAnswer: Faith often grows through repeated reassurance
questions.explanation: Judges 6:37-40 shows Gideon asking God for two signs with the fleece, illustrating that biblical faith can develop through gradual confirmation and divine patience.

theological.title: Judges Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Judges Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the initial cause of Israel's suffering under the Midianites as described in Judges 6?
options: The children of Israel did evil in the sight of the LORD
God was testing Israel's faith
The Midianites were stronger warriors
Israel refused to fight
questions.correctAnswer: The children of Israel did evil in the sight of the LORD
questions.explanation: Judges 6:1 states that Israel did evil in the sight of the LORD, which led to their deliverance into Midian's hand. This reflects the biblical theme of sin bringing judgment (Romans 1:18), God's righteous discipline (Hebrews 12:6), and calls for repentance (2 Chronicles 7:14).

questions.question: According to Judges 6, why did the Israelites hide their wheat in dens, caves, and strongholds?
options: Because the Midianites prevailed against them
To prepare for a great famine
To protect it from the Israelites themselves
Because God commanded it
questions.correctAnswer: Because the Midianites prevailed against them
questions.explanation: Judges 6:2 describes how the Midianites oppressed Israel, forcing them to hide their produce in dens and caves. This shows how sin leads to vulnerability and oppression (Psalm 37:39), and highlights human frailty before God's judgment and mercy (Isaiah 1:5-6).

questions.question: In Judges 6, which groups came against Israel to destroy their crops and livestock?
options: Midianites, Amalekites, and the children of the east
Philistines, Moabites, and Edomites
Babylonians, Assyrians, and Egyptians
Amalekites, Hittites, and Canaanites
questions.correctAnswer: Midianites, Amalekites, and the children of the east
questions.explanation: Judges 6:3 states these three groups came up against Israel. This coalition illustrates the external threats faced due to internal apostasy, consistent with God's covenantal warnings (Deuteronomy 28:49-50) and the biblical principle that sin brings enemies (Psalm 18:40).

questions.question: How does Judges 6 describe the multitude of the Midianites and their camels?
options: They came as grasshoppers for multitude
They were a small, manageable group
They camouflaged themselves in the mountains
They came silently by night
questions.correctAnswer: They came as grasshoppers for multitude
questions.explanation: Judges 6:5 uses the metaphor of grasshoppers to emphasize the overwhelming number of Midianites, reflecting biblical depictions of overwhelming enemies (Exodus 10:14, Revelation 9:3). This underscores human helplessness apart from divine intervention (Psalm 44:3).

questions.question: What was Israel's response to their oppression by Midian according to Judges 6?
options: They cried unto the LORD
They made a political alliance
They fled to neighboring lands
They built stronger fortresses
questions.correctAnswer: They cried unto the LORD
questions.explanation: Judges 6:6-7 records Israel crying out to the LORD, a biblical motif of repentance and seeking divine help (Psalm 50:15, Jeremiah 33:3). This shows God's readiness to respond to contrite hearts (Isaiah 57:15) and the necessity of prayer in salvation (Philippians 4:6).

questions.question: What message did the prophet sent by the LORD convey to Israel in Judges 6?
options: God had delivered them from Egypt and given them the land, but they did not obey His voice
They would be victorious without repentance
God had forsaken them permanently
They should worship the gods of the Amorites
questions.correctAnswer: God had delivered them from Egypt and given them the land, but they did not obey His voice
questions.explanation: In Judges 6:8-10, the prophet reminds Israel of God's past saving acts and their failure to obey Him. This reveals God’s faithfulness contrasted with human disobedience (Deuteronomy 7:8, Hebrews 13:5), highlighting the covenantal relationship and the need for obedience (John 14:15).

questions.question: How does the angel of the LORD address Gideon when he appears to him?
options: The LORD is with thee, thou mighty man of valor
Fear not, for you are chosen above all
Go and hide from the Midianites
You are weak, but will be strong
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is with thee, thou mighty man of valor
questions.explanation: Judges 6:12 reveals the angel’s greeting, affirming God's empowering presence. This highlights God's ability to use the weak for His purposes (1 Corinthians 1:27), and the doctrine of divine calling and empowerment (Acts 9:15).

questions.question: What objection does Gideon raise to the angel's greeting in Judges 6?
options: If the LORD is with us, why has all this happened to us?
I am too young and inexperienced
I do not believe in angels
The LORD has forgotten His promises
questions.correctAnswer: If the LORD is with us, why has all this happened to us?
questions.explanation: Judges 6:13 shows Gideon's doubt reflecting the problem of theodicy—why God allows suffering. This question aligns with biblical wrestling with divine justice (Habakkuk 1:2-4, Job 3:11) and God's ultimate purpose in suffering (Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What assurance does the LORD give to Gideon about saving Israel?
options: Surely I will be with thee, and thou shalt smite the Midianites as one man
You must gather a large army to defeat them
God will send another judge
Israel will save itself
questions.correctAnswer: Surely I will be with thee, and thou shalt smite the Midianites as one man
questions.explanation: Judges 6:16 promises God's presence and power to Gideon, emphasizing salvation through divine enablement (Exodus 3:12, Joshua 1:5). This reflects God's sovereignty and grace in salvation (Ephesians 2:8-9).

questions.question: What sign does Gideon ask from God to confirm his calling?
options: A sign involving a fleece of wool with dew
A burning bush
A voice from heaven
A dream of victory
questions.correctAnswer: A sign involving a fleece of wool with dew
questions.explanation: Judges 6:36-37 describes Gideon’s request for a sign with a fleece. This sign-seeking reflects human desire for confirmation of God's promises (Exodus 4:1-9, Isaiah 7:10-14), while God graciously accommodates faith (Hebrews 11:1).

questions.question: How does God respond to Gideon's fleece test?
options: God makes the fleece wet with dew but the ground dry, and then reverses it
God ignores the request
God sends a thunderstorm
God speaks audibly to Gideon
questions.correctAnswer: God makes the fleece wet with dew but the ground dry, and then reverses it
questions.explanation: Judges 6:38-40 records God’s response, demonstrating His patience and willingness to confirm His call. This underscores God's gracious accommodation to human weakness (Psalm 86:15) and the importance of faith and trust (Proverbs 3:5-6).

questions.question: What significant action does Gideon take against idolatry in his father's house?
options: He tears down the altar of Baal and cuts down the grove
He builds a new altar for Baal
He consecrates the grove as holy
He ignores it to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: He tears down the altar of Baal and cuts down the grove
questions.explanation: Judges 6:25-27 describes Gideon's destruction of Baal's altar, illustrating the biblical call to reject false gods (Exodus 20:3-5, 1 Corinthians 10:14). This act prefigures Christ's cleansing of the temple (John 2:15-17) and the call to holiness (1 Peter 1:16).

questions.question: What new name is given to Gideon, and what does it mean?
options: Jerubbaal, meaning 'Let Baal plead against him'
Elijah, meaning 'My God is Yahweh'
Nathaniel, meaning 'Gift of God'
Barak, meaning 'Lightning'
questions.correctAnswer: Jerubbaal, meaning 'Let Baal plead against him'
questions.explanation: Judges 6:32 reveals Gideon's new name Jerubbaal, signifying confrontation with false gods. This renaming signifies new identity and mission, a biblical theme (Genesis 17:5, Isaiah 62:2), and points to Christ as the true deliverer (Acts 4:12).

questions.question: What was the Spirit of the LORD's role in Gideon's leadership as described in Judges 6?
options: The Spirit came upon Gideon empowering him to gather Israel
The Spirit abandoned Gideon
The Spirit appeared as a dove
The Spirit gave Gideon a vision but no power
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit came upon Gideon empowering him to gather Israel
questions.explanation: Judges 6:34 states the Spirit of the LORD came upon Gideon, enabling his leadership. This highlights the biblical teaching on the Holy Spirit empowering God's servants (Judges 3:10, Acts 1:8), affirming pneumatology and divine guidance.

questions.question: What theological theme is illustrated by the LORD sending a prophet to remind Israel of His deliverance and their disobedience?
options: God's covenant faithfulness and Israel's need for repentance
God's indifference to human sin
Human effort achieves salvation
Idolatry is acceptable
questions.correctAnswer: God's covenant faithfulness and Israel's need for repentance
questions.explanation: Judges 6:8-10 shows the prophet's message emphasizing God's faithfulness despite Israel's failures, calling them to repent. This reflects covenant theology (Jeremiah 31:33), God’s mercy (Exodus 34:6), and the necessity of repentance (Luke 13:3).

questions.question: What does Gideon's request for a sign suggest about human nature and faith?
options: That humans often seek reassurance before trusting God fully
That faith requires no evidence
That signs are unnecessary and always sinful
That God never provides confirmation
questions.correctAnswer: That humans often seek reassurance before trusting God fully
questions.explanation: Judges 6:36-40 shows Gideon's desire for a sign indicating human tendency to need assurance (John 20:24-29). God’s accommodation illustrates grace (2 Corinthians 12:9), while Scripture calls believers to trust God’s promises (Hebrews 11:1).
